title.narrative: Strengthening the provision of WASH assistance and setting up a multi sectorial Rapid Response Mechanism to respond to lifesaving needs in highly vulnerable areas in Borno State (Bama, Dikwa and Monguno LGAs for WASH and Bama, Gwoza, Ngala, Kala-Balge and Mobbar for RRM)

description.narrative:
Forced displacements, acute food shortages, and lack of toilet facilities force affected communities to defecate openly. This violates dignity of the IDPs living in formal/informal camps and in host communities and increases the threat of transmission of diseases in case of outbreaks. Coupled with a lack of clean water, malnutrition rates among children under five worsen. In the 2017 Nigeria HRP, the WASH sector is seeking USD 49.7m targeting a population of 1,978,000 it was 17.6% funded at June 2017. UNICEF targets 1,028,000 people (52% of sector targets) with hygiene and safe water activities 217,000 people with improved sanitation facilities. WASH outcomes enforce outcomes for nutrition, education, health and protection.
The project has two components:
(a) Enhancing the provision of basic WASH services to (i) sustain WASH services meeting the Nigerian Humanitarian standards and expand improvements towards reaching the SPHERE standards (ii) Sustain hygiene promotion for personal hygiene and prevention of disease outbreaks such as cholera, diarrhoea and hepatitis. Priority is given to IDP camps and returnee areas, focusing on Bama, Dikwa and Monguno LGAs. This component will be implemented through existing partnerships with RUWASSA and expanded Project Cooperation Agreements (PCA) with INGOs. RUWASSA and its affiliated contractors will implement the latrine construction and water sources development/upgrading. Implementation will be managed in lots per location and IDP camps. The management of implementation of the lots will be partly through PCA with INGOs (intended: DRC in Banki and Bama OXFAM in Dikwa and ACF in Monguno) and partly directly by UNICEF Project Officers. Other resources will be used to support the project management structures.
(b) Contributing to the set-up of a multi-sectorial Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) to respond to urgent needs , through a timely delivery of a minimum package of high impact interventions covering WASH, Nutrition, NFI, Food security and Health as well as Protection mainstreaming. The RRM will respond in a timely, coordinated manner to the needs of populations made vulnerable by conflict, disease and/or natural disaster, in hard to reach areas where there is no or not enough humanitarian capacity. Through its partners on the ground RRM will set up an efficient early warning system thus ensuring the timely reception of alerts that will enable the activation of the Mechanism. An RRM structure is in place in Maiduguri composed of several NGOs, WFP, UNICEF, IOM, and WHO, and coordinated by OCHA. This project will enhance the capacity of the RRM, in the following priority LGAs : Bama, Gwoza, Ngala, Kala-Balge and Mobbar.
